story.text: Evolution of Incident Management at Slack. Brent Chapman @ SRECon2021. Learn how we've made incident management a core capability of everyone on our engineering team: where we are, how we got here, and where we're going. Brent has basically given everyone a roadmap to building an effective incident response program. [https://www.usenix.org/conference/srecon21/presentation/chapman usenix] [https://www.usenix.org/system/files/srecon21_slides_chapman.pdf pdf] [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FYYTglQoS3w youtube]

YOUTUBE FYYTglQoS3w
Evolution of Incident Management at Slack. Brent Chapman @ SRECon2021. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FYYTglQoS3w youtube]
September 2018, slack suffered a reliability crisis.

Introduced Service Ownership model. Dismantled their old operations team and replaced with you-build-it-you-run-it model. (This change aligned with practices among other leaders in software industry. See [[Who Owns On-Call?]])

story.text:
# Vision
1. IM recognized as key capability for company
1. IM practices consistent across company
1. IM capabilities at all levels of the org
1. Effective mechanisms for developing and strengthening IM capabilities
1. Routinely conduct blameless or blame-aware reviews

# Plan & Execution
1. ~~Awareness training during onboarding (1h)~~
1. Responder training for all Engineers (3h)
1. Leadership training for experienced responders (3h)
1. ~~Refresher training for experienced responders & leaders~~
1. ~~Exercises to enable people to practice their IM skills~~

Awareness training proved unnecessary. Refresher training made unnecessary because tempo of real incidents keeps skills sharp anyway. The exercises didn't survive the pandemicâ€”proved too hard to run remotely.
Video goes on to describe the introduction of Major Incident Commander role in some detail and some short comments about review and analysis.

Evolution of Incident Management at Slack. Brent Chapman @ SRECon2021. Learn how we've made incident management a core capability of everyone on our engineering team: where we are, how we got here, and where we're going. Brent has basically given everyone a roadmap to building an effective incident response program. [https://www.usenix.org/conference/srecon21/presentation/chapman usenix] [https://www.usenix.org/system/files/srecon21_slides_chapman.pdf pdf] [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FYYTglQoS3w youtube]

item.text: YOUTUBE

YOUTUBE 
Evolution of Incident Management at Slack. Brent Chapman @ SRECon2021. [ youtube]

YOUTUBE FYYTglQoS3w
Evolution of Incident Management at Slack. Brent Chapman @ SRECon2021. [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=FYYTglQoS3w youtube]
September 2018, slack suffered a reliability crisis.
Introduced deploy commander.

Introduced rotating role of deploy commander. Deploys went first to internal social and engineering workspaces so slack could feel any pain first before deploys roll out to customers. Deploys roll out to the entire fleet in about an hour.
Introduced

Introduced Service Ownership model. Dismantled their old operations team and replaced with you-build-it-you-run-it model. (This change aligned with practices among other leaders in software industry. See [[Who Owns On-Call?]])

item.text: Vision

1. IM recognized as key capability for company
1. IM practices consistent across company
1. IM capabilities at all levels of the org
1. Effective mechanisms for developing and strengthening IM capabilities
1. Routinely conduct blameless or blame-aware reviews

# Vision
1. IM recognized as key capability for company
1. IM practices consistent across company
1. IM capabilities at all levels of the org
1. Effective mechanisms for developing and strengthening IM capabilities
1. Routinely conduct blameless or blame-aware reviews

# Vision
1. IM recognized as key capability for company
1. IM practices consistent across company
1. IM capabilities at all levels of the org
1. Effective mechanisms for developing and strengthening IM capabilities
1. Routinely conduct blameless or blame-aware reviews

# Plan
1.

# Plan
1. Awareness training during onboarding (1h)
1. Responder training for all Engineers (3h)
1. Leadership training for experienced responders (3h)
1. Refresher training for experienced responders & leaders
1. Exercises to enable people to practice their IM skills.

# Plan & Execution
1. ~Awareness training during onboarding (1h)~
1. Responder training for all Engineers (3h)
1. Leadership training for experienced responders (3h)
1. ~Refresher training for experienced responders & leaders~
1. Exercises to enable people to practice their IM skills.

# Plan & Execution
1. ~~Awareness training during onboarding (1h)~~
1. Responder training for all Engineers (3h)
1. Leadership training for experienced responders (3h)
1. ~~Refresher training for experienced responders & leaders~~
1. Exercises to enable people to practice their IM skills.

# Plan & Execution
1. ~~Awareness training during onboarding (1h)~~
1. Responder training for all Engineers (3h)
1. Leadership training for experienced responders (3h)
1. ~~Refresher training for experienced responders & leaders~~
1. ~~Exercises to enable people to practice their IM skills~~

Awareness training proved unnecessary. Refresher training made unnecessary because tempo of real incidents keeps skills sharp anyway. The exercises didn't survive the pandemicâ€”proved too hard to run remotely.
Video goes on to describe the introduction of Major Incident Commander role in some detail and some short comments about review and analysis.
